docs.lead_paragraph: A SAMPLE of Karin Laakso's white blood cells were siphoned off and made into a personal cancer vaccine, which she was given once a week for four weeks, followed by one dose per month for three months. ''It's marvelous. It's made from your own body, and has no negative side effects,'' said Ms. Laakso, a registered nurse whose chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a slow-growing cancer, was diagnosed 14 years ago. After the fifth vaccine injection in April, tests indicated her immune systems T-cells were attacking the malignant cells.

headline.main: A New Generation of Cancer Vaccines

docs.abstract: University of Connectict Cancer Research Center, Yale Cancer Center and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co in Wallingford, Conn, are developing several cancer vaccines; vaccines, made from patients' cells or synthetically, are often intended to treat existing disease rather than prevent it; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A major new entitlement program, paid for with a major new tax. Sounds more like Bill Bradley than Trent Lott, right? In this case, the political figure embracing the deal is a Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, and while the plan is likely to sell well in New York, it puts Mr. Pataki at odds with most of his party's leading figures around the country.

headline.main: Political Memo; Health Insurance Proposal Puts Pataki At Odds With Most Republican Leaders

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki's embrace of program to subsidize health insurance for as many as half million low- and moderate-income people who do not qualify for Medicaid puts him at odds with most of Republican Party's leading figures around country (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S the peak of the holiday season, and the air is filled with apocalyptic warnings tied to the turn of the millennium. But there is plenty more to worry about than serious threats like terrorism, doomsday cults and Y2K calamities. As usual at this time of year, the perennial peril profiteers, seasonal scolds and year-end yentas are busy issuing warnings and advice on more mundane dangers. And with the clock winding down on the century, the worry warts are in full throat, as evidenced by the following alarming bulletins culled from recent press releases and news reports. JOE SHARKEY

headline.main: Word for Word/Seasonal Scolding; Flying Corks, Killer Poinsettias And Other Holiday Hazards

docs.abstract: Excerpts from recent press releases and news reports about Christmas and New Year holiday season perils; photo (M)6

docs.lead_paragraph: Spurred by an Institute of Medicine report last month, big employers, health care organizations, state regulators and the federal government are stepping up pressure to revamp a health care system that calls itself the best in the world, yet hides and ignores mistakes that kill tens of thousands of patients a year. Largely in response to the report, eight executives of some of the nation's biggest companies, including General Motors and General Electric, disclosed this week that they had formed an organization they call The Leapfrog Group to encourage all employers to make safe medicine a top priority of the health insurance they provide their workers and to steer workers to hospitals that make the fewest mistakes.

headline.main: AMBITIOUS EFFORT TO CUT MISTAKES IN U.S. HOSPITALS

docs.abstract: Big employers, health care organizations and state and federal government take steps to confront mistakes in nation's hospitals, which kill 44,000 to 98,000 people a year, according to recent report by Institute of Medicine; patient advocates and some regulators still warn that for most hospitals and physicians a culture of defensiveness and secretiveness is deeply ingrained and will be difficult to change; others say institute's report does not go far enough in making demands on health care industry, such as insisting on more autopsies; enforcing the disclosure rules advocated by institute is expected to be difficult (M)
docs.snippet: Spurred by an Institute of Medicine report last month, big employers, health care organizations, state regulators and the federal government are stepping up pressure to revamp a health care system that calls itself the best in the world, yet hides...

docs.lead_paragraph: DIANE and Keith Triolo grew up in Huntington and work there, she as a claims adjuster for an insurance company, he for a local construction firm. Now they live there again, moving in September with their two young children from a rental apartment in Holbrook to a three-bedroom semiattached town house in a Melville development called the Villages at Huntington, which will include 248 units on 92 acres when completed.

headline.main: In the Region/Long Island; A Push for Low-Cost Housing on Surplus State Land

docs.abstract: Advocates for moderately priced housing are pressing for construction of some affordable housing on surplus psychiatric hospital properties being sold to developers by New York State; urge developers be allowed to build more units per acre in return for making percentage of houses available at lower prices to families who meet income restrictions; photo (In the Region/Long Island) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This 30-second commercial is the seventh from Vice President Al Gore. It discusses his experience and is being broadcast in Iowa and New Hampshire beginning this weekend. PRODUCER Century-Media. ON THE SCREEN -- The question is posed on a black screen: ''How much experience does America need?'' Live color shots of Mr. Gore with regular people appear sequentially as he talks about Social Security (he hugs an elderly person), schools (a teacher appears with children in a classroom), the environment (a spray of cherry blossoms) and the economy (a roof-raising). Mr. Gore appears at the end in a blue suit reviewing a piece of paper.
docs.abstract: Appraisal of 30-second commercial from Vice Pres Al Gore's campaign being broadcast in Iowa and New Hamsphire; it discusses his experience and inches closer to direct attack on proposals made by Bill Bradley, though it does not name him; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brandishing new data showing that the drug industry earns higher profits and pays lower taxes than most other industries, White House officials say drug companies may bring price controls on themselves if they continue to resist President Clinton's plan to have Medicare provide pharmaceutical benefits. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly said that his proposal for Medicare drug benefits does not envision federal regulation of drug prices, and such a measure is highly unlikely. But the statements from the officials suggest that the White House is taking a harder line as an election year approaches.

headline.main: Drug Industry Under Pressure From President

docs.abstract: White House says drug companies may bring price controls on themselves if they continue to resist Pres Clinton's plan to have Medicare provide pharmaceutical benefits; cites new data showing that drug industry earns higher profits and pays lower taxes than most other industries; Clinton has repeatedly said his proposal for Medicare drug benefits does not envision federal regulation of drug prices, but latest statement from White House officials suggests he may take harder line as election year approaches (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The landmark agreement reached by Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature to provide medical coverage for the poor by raising the state's cigarette tax contains a little-noticed provision denying those benefits to thousands of legal immigrants during their first five years in the country. The measure was included at the insistence of Governor Pataki, a Republican who has sought to exclude new immigrants from other forms of public assistance as part of his overall drive to sharply reduce state spending on a host of programs for the poor.

headline.main: Health Plan Would Not Aid All Uninsured

docs.abstract: Agreement between New York legislators and Gov George Pataki to provide medical coverage for the poor by raising cigarette tax contains little-noticed provision denying benefits to legal immigrants during their first five years in US; Pataki insisted on clause, because federal immigration law requires that sponsors, not taxpayers, be responsible for new immigrants; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani objects (M)
docs.snippet: The landmark agreement reached by Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature to provide medical coverage for the poor by raising the state's cigarette tax contains a little-noticed provision denying those benefits to thousands of legal immigrants...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Health Care Proposals Help Define Democrats'' (news article, Dec. 20): Vice President Al Gore has said that ''no one'' would be left out under his health care plan.
docs.abstract: Letter from George N Spitz calls on Vice Pres Al Gore to give cost estimate for his system of providing health care coverage for everybody, as Bill Bradley has done (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge who once represented a police officer in a lawsuit over a controversial on-duty shooting was picked yesterday to preside over the trial of the four officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo last February. Before his election to the bench in 1993, Justice Joseph C. Teresi of State Supreme Court in Albany was also a longtime public defender, something court officials eagerly highlighted, apparently to assuage any concerns that Albany judges are generally pro-police.

headline.main: Judge With Reputation for Toughness is Chosen for the Diallo Trial
